title: Let's Talk About (The Core Concepts Of) Yorick...
body:
If it's not clear by now, I'm a huge fan of Yorick, the Grave Digger.  Spamming ghouls and being a tough to kill tank is a lot of fun.  It's also clear that Narrative (Jaredan specifically) only wants to talk about “core concepts” of a champion and not story ideas or examples.

However, I'm also not one to shy away from games, not matter the rules, so I'll give it a shot.  I'm probably going to fail at some point in keeping it to just “core concepts” since a great deal of my thoughts require that I give examples.  However, if a Rioter wants examples or me to elaborate on points further, I can certainly try.
- - - - -
Yorick, at his base, is a grave digger and mortician.  Similar to ditch diggers, this is as blue collar a job as you can get, an aspect of League's lore and world that isn't dealt with nearly as much as it could be.  As the “Grave Digger” of Runeterra, Yorick's job on the Shadow Isles is to clean up the messes left behind by the other champions, whether that's Elise looking for a snack or Karthus preparing for his next concert.

Yorick does his job, rests in the manner that ghouls rest on Runeterra, then does it all again the next day.

In other words, Yorick has more in common with Helmet Bro than any of the “best and brightest” champions commonly seen on Runeterra.

(I'm going to stop here at the moment since talking further would likely lead to me giving story ideas.  If anyone from Narrative would like me to elaborate on certain things, however, I'm willing to play.)

replies.body:
I like the themes of him being the long-suffering, humble, honor-through-hard-work sort of guy.  The one who's seen so much that little surprises him any more.  Reminds me of the old security guard in the [Avengers deleted scene](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ed6ecXCoZOk), even if the comparison is a *bit* off.

It's as if - the most incredible things could (and have) happened in front of him, but he mostly ignores it in favor of doing his job.  It's not that he's unintelligent, it's just that he's got a job that never ends, and if he doesn't do it, no-one else will.  Maybe he can epitomize quiet strength and extreme persistence.

> It's as if - the most incredible things could (and have) happened in front of him, but he mostly ignores it in favor of doing his job.  It's not that he's unintelligent, it's just that he's got a job that never ends, and if he doesn't do it, no-one else will.  Maybe he can epitomize quiet strength and extreme persistence.

That's pretty much what I went with in a recent Factions update. Yorick is the POV character in the third scene of **[The Harrowing](http://leaguefactions.net/nyroth-update-5/)**; the section is marked with Yorick's splash art, if you want to skim down. (He also makes a brief appearance in the first scene.) I think the "blue collar" or "workman" elements are pretty strong, and a nice contrast to other Champions, who are often rather aristocratic. He also draws a bit of pathos from his Sisyphean task. Actually, he's got it worse than Sisyphus in a way: at least Sisyphus knew where the boulder was at any given time. I wouldn't say that Yorick has a "heart of gold", exactly, and his grudging misanthropy goes pretty deep, but he's not really that bad of a guy, and he's still got a heart, at least figuratively.

In addition to "quiet strength and extreme persistence", I'd add that he also has a certain pride in his craft. He does good work. It matters to him that he does good work, and not just because he thinks it might be part of his "quota". He does good work because Yorick Mori does good work. He's no softie, and his outward resentment toward the dead (who incessantly beg him for peace) is generally quite heartfelt. But I think sometimes there's an intersection of his pride and his grudging sympathy for these poor saps that resolves into something like kindness. He's jaded, sure, but he does feel kind of badly for the restless dead, and every now and then, he gets some satisfaction from doing them a final service, and doing it right, after everyone else has forgotten about them.

---

Since there's been some fanfic apprehension, let me add what I think should go without saying: I'm very grateful that Riot encourages the community to create community lore, and I can scarcely fathom the temerity that would be required for a League community member to try to sue Riot for reading or using community lore. It's rather presumptuous for me to even say this, but for the sake of clarity: if Riot wants to use elements from this post, the linked story, or anything I've written League-wise, I would have no objection whatsoever. To get preposterous as well as presumptuous, I'd even add (I think quite needlessly) that I release any legal right to object to any such use, other than perhaps verbatim copy-pasting without attribution. I don't think this is going to happen, but for the sake of illustration, if you and Jaredan decided to write a story about Yorick going to Nyroth and digging up some lost souls, including some direct quotes from this piece, my reaction would be giddy delight, not litigiousness (that I'd in any event hopefully be sanctioned and fined for wasting a court's time with). Really, this should all go entirely without saying: we post stuff on these forums precisely because we want to contribute to the effort. It's not just that we're okay with Riot using our ideas: we're posting our ideas **because** we want Riot to use them. If I post some silly fanfic and it gives a Riot author an idea, I **want** them to use it. Permission is deeply implied in the understood nature of the relationship.

That said, I'll just link it rather than quoting from it here, in case any Rioters start having conniptions about legal liability. (Though seriously, talk to your legal team. If they're not idiots, and I have it on good authority that they're not, they should be able to put you at ease and demolish this needless barrier to Riot-community engagement. IP law is broken, but it's not **that** broken.)

Not to derail this thread into a fanfic debate, but…whatever ethical or legal concerns Narrative has about reading specific story ideas, I'm pretty sure they're conclusively resolved by the author saying "I am putting this forward in the hopes of you using it, and I freely release all ideas contained herein to you." That's an express statement of what's pretty strongly implied by context. Besides, I've yet to see anyone point to an authoritative judicial opinion that stands for the (ludicrous) proposition that any type of IP right attaches to a general story concept.

That said, it's not like there are that many novel story ideas in that link anyway. It's "Yorick digs graves for dead people". The main purpose is to illustrate some ideas about his personality.

I'm very, very reluctant to do anything to increase Rioter or community anxiety about "legal problems". We have enough problems getting communication going; we don't need to add onto them by building up an unfounded sense of paranoia about the flow of ideas.

**tl;dr: If any Rioters honestly believe that they can't read fanfic or use specific story ideas as a way to get at a character's essential personality, they need to go talk to their legal team and get some clarification, because that sort of belief is a major (and needless) impediment to community interaction. Imagine if Meddler felt he couldn't read specific ideas for Champion changes, or IronStylus couldn't look at fan art.**

Not only that, but I'm trying, very carefully, to play by those rules as well.  Your repeated insistence on convincing Jaredan otherwise is disrespectful to both Narrative and myself.

If you want to post your own thoughts on their ludicrous reasoning, it should have been done in your own thread, not through hijacking someone else's unrelated thread.

> [{quoted}](name=TerraRising,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=f0xMkWEc,comment-id=00080000000000000000,timestamp=2015-03-20T23:58:36.344+0000)

I don't think it's completely clear what "the rules" are, and I think we should be very careful about codifying for ourselves a set of "the rules" that will prevent us from communicating openly. You're right: perhaps the longer discussion does belong in a separate thread. But, respectfully, **you're** the one who raised the "taboo" in the first place in this thread. I felt a need to respond. I think there's a real danger that community members will read casual references to "the rules" and begin silencing themselves. The costs of such self-policing can be very high indeed.

My understanding of "the rules" against discussing "story ideas" is that, if Narrative is working on a specific story, they don't want to start collaborating on that specific story with the community, because then its authorship becomes blurry. Instead, they want to hear about the basic elements of the characters, or the themes you'd like to explore. A story idea, or a "fanfic", or a bit of sample dialogue, may be helpful in illustrating these basic elements; it's often much more natural to use specifics than to talk in broad abstractions. They can correct me if I'm wrong, but I don't read anything that they've said as a command to not use specific examples: it's just that they can't use story ideas, and the story ideas themselves are not useful to them (but they may still contribute useful material).

Your understanding, if I'm interpreting your comments correctly, is that there's a ban on mentioning story ideas even in general terms, like, "I think it'd be cool to see Mundo and Warwick fight. Maybe on top of a skyscraper in Zaun," because after reading that, a Rioter is forever prevented from writing a story about Mundo and Warwick fighting on top of a skyscraper in Zaun. I do not think that's the case, and I certainly don't think that means that they must go and scrap all draft stories they're working on that involve Mundo and Warwick fighting on top of a skyscraper in Zaun. There's certainly no legal reason for that.

I imagine you were just trying to be cautious, but there's a real danger to throwing in so many "gosh, I'm probably breaking the rules, but, maybe, can I sort of vaguely suggest that I'd like stories about, you know, Yorick and his past? Sorry! I may have said too much. Forgive me." comments, because they might give others the impression that we're not allowed to talk about stories on the Story and Art board.

Also, I'd point out that in this very thread, Bioluminesence and I are talking about fairly specific story scenarios. The goal is not to start writing a story together, but rather to explore a character (Yorick) by discussing some scenarios he might find himself in, or how he conducts himself. I don't believe that Narrative has any problem with that, and I can't imagine why they would, so I'm loath to begin spreading it as gospel that this is somehow forbidden.

> [{quoted}](name=TerraRising,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=f0xMkWEc,comment-id=0008000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2015-03-21T03:19:03.983+0000)

And now you're accusing me not only of being incorrect but of having "selfish reasons" for wanting us to be able to talk with Riot's story-writers about stories. I really wasn't expecting this kind of behavior from you. I disagreed with your positions, but I never doubted your motivations.

Out of respect for your request, I'll refrain from further discussion of the particulars of what I think Rioters think is okay or not okay. I say we leave it to them, and trust them to speak up as needed. They're grown-ups. They can do that. Suffice it to say that I think you're incorrect. I don't think you have "selfish reasons"—I think you're just very anxious to the point of error.

I'm not really interested in getting in some kind of personal brawl with you over this. You're not my enemy. But if we're going to speak plainly, then I'll put it this way: you're afraid of scaring Rioters, and so you defensively buffer your posts with apologetic remarks about "the rules". In the process, I think you're scaring the community, spreading the idea that we can't talk about Champions except in the most abstract terms. Although I don't believe you're acting out of malice, I will say that I think you're doing harm, and should reconsider your modus operandi. The last thing we need is to make our own community paranoid about talking to Rioters. Telling people not to post "story ideas" is turning down the volume at a time when we're already having trouble being heard.

And I will go further to say that, in the process, you are being deeply disrespectful to the community. You're telling content creators to hide what they've done, as though they should be ashamed of it. It's not me you need to worry about. You can yell at me all day. Go to town. The person I'm worried about is the community author or artist standing on the sidelines right now, who was all ready to come forth and pitch some ideas for a Champion, using their own work as illustration, and will now stay quiet because you've shamed them out of it. And implied that it's their fault—our fault—that Narrative hasn't interacted with us in the past, or that it will be our fault if they don't in the future. Sorry, no. This theory that Narrative staffers are delicate butterflies who are so terrified of people posting whatever "story ideas" might be, I don't accept it, and I think it's perverse to start making up reasons why the long silence is our fault. Stop putting these Rioters up on so high a pedestal: that's part of the problem. You're jumping at shadows, so scared of offending them that you aren't saying anything at all.

I think you have the best of intentions. Or rather, you did, up unto the point where you attacked one of your own comrades. Snap out of it.

> [{quoted}](name=Lord Graves III,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=f0xMkWEc,comment-id=0009,timestamp=2015-03-20T19:31:12.165+0000)

How do you think that controlling and aggressive aspect of him ties with what others are saying about him being the 'every-ghoul' salt-of-the-earth type of guy?  Do you think those aspects are in conflict, or do you think they work well and create depth?

> [{quoted}](name=Bioluminescence,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=f0xMkWEc,comment-id=00090000,timestamp=2015-03-20T20:26:07.141+0000)

(I want to read Lord Graves III's reply, but at the risk of breaching decorum, I'm also going to add in an answer of my own.)

My first thought: Picking a fight with Yorick sounds a lot like picking a fight with a construction foreman and his boys. Their job is beating up the earth all day. It's probably going to hurt when they turn that muscle and metal on you instead.

My next thought: Well, but the ghouls don't exactly have little hardhats on. Are they even clearly the souls of the dead, or just, well, omens? Maybe they're beasties from the "other side"?

I admit I'm not really sure where his ghouls fit in storywise, especially with their horsemen-esque monikers (War, Famine, Pestilence, Death). I hadn't thought much about that. Off the cuff, I'd reach for an analogy about "calling out the guys for a big job". If he's a "working" Champion, it seems appropriate that he might have a ghoulish work-gang. As for the War/Famine/Pestilence/Death bit, I don't know. Maybe he's got an innate understanding of the forces that send jobs his way. Or maybe that's a point to add something else into the mix: he doesn't have to just be a one-note "blue collar Champion". Maybe those forces are tied to whatever brought him "back" and gave him his "quota".

The other thing is that, off the Fields, it's not immediately clear why Yorick would be fighting anyone. I was going to say that maybe Demacians or Ionians might get in the way of him and a job, but…that doesn't seem quite right. It's not like he has an actual army, and even as a Champion, I don't think he has the capability (or inclination) to go violating sovereign territory and taking on the heavy-hitters. I guess if Mordekaiser sent out a big army, he might follow in their wake. Perhaps he could show up in a plague-stricken area and start digging…and maybe have to fight off some local folk who don't take kindly to his spooky intrusion? But that's not exactly a recipe for an epic battle: Yorick the Champion against "some guys". Ehhhhhhh. Maybe if there's some controversy, e.g. Ionia wants to do its own funerary rites, and Yorick wants to do his, there might be a brawl with some Champs on the other side, and maybe he'd get backup from some other SI Champions, but it seems really hard to keep that from blowing up into a much larger fight. I guess if he appeared out of nowhere, and there were only one or two Ionian Champions nearby? It might be workable. And, unlike Demacia, Ionia might have reservations about just (e.g.) going on a smite-rampage to destroy the Shadow Isles in retaliation, figuring that such an act would cause a lot more damage to the cosmic balance. So, okay. Yeah. Might work. I take it back; I can see how Yorick might get into a fight off the Fields.

Or, oooh, hey. Another idea for him getting into fights. It seems pretty clear that the Isles aren't totally monolithic. For example, Morde/Hecarim/Thresh seem to have a decidedly more (from a human perspective) "malevolent" attitude toward the dead, turning them into armies with which to conquer the mortal world. Maybe Yorick gets into fights with them sometimes over souls. That's even better "diplomatically": that's a purely internal matter.

I sort of like the idea that he's a protector, or maybe... keeper of the dead.  That digging up corpses is like someone running with muddy boots in the hallway he just mopped - I just cleaned that!  Maybe he believes he knows best in that regard - that magics used to cheat death, or other corpse raising, are to be pitied and patiently put back in the ground.  One day, he might hope that he'll be able to rest - but until he does, he'll work to get others get there.  

That could create some conflict with his ghouls.  Maybe the ghouls get to hang around because he's lonely - maybe they're attracted to him and he's been unable to keep them in the ground (like Yorick), so he tolerates their presence.  I dunno!

I find Yorick's visual design to be antiquated; there's very little focus to his shape, theme or in-game read. One of the more prominent features of his model appears to be the lantern strapped to his back, yet it plays no role in his kit nor does it react when he attacks or casts spells. Likewise the shovel – which players link to his character – isn’t used for anything other than his Q. Finally his ghoul summons (the focus of his entire kit) all look very weak, are mechanically uninteractive, and ultimately come off as boring. 

Yorick needs a visual rework to modernize his look and bring him in line with more recent Shadow Isles champions. Bring in the ethereal green/blue wisps of spirit energy, and make it seem as though Yorick is a corpse animated by the Isles’ power. Likewise, make him appear to pour that power into the earth in order to summon minions. His visual style and theme will be all the more cohesive for it. 

Gameplay wise, there seems to be a clash of archetypes between Yorick being an undead bruiser due to his hunch-back shovel-hitting stature, and a necromancer with his ghouls. Given that Sion is already League’s undead Juggernaut, there’s reasonable cause to think Yorick should be pushed towards being the Necromancer of the game. The way the ghouls work currently allows Yorick to punish his lane enemies too easy as soon as they try to farm or get within cast range. Furthermore, the ghouls act more like spell missiles with health rather than proper minions. Zzrot’s portal – in my opinion – brings an interesting lane pushing mechanic that could be adapted to a Necromancer’s kit in the game. 

One thing’s for sure though; Yorick will require a full rework in order for him to see the light.

I honestly don't know how I could have possibly crammed more concise visual/art critique in this post.

Riot isn't currently writing developed lore for any of its characters, new and old alike, so my critique is based off elements they are consistently delivering on - Art, gameplay, theme.

Personally, I think the sort of 'Blue Collar' sort of theme that Yorick has wouldn't normally be especially interesting, or important, EXCEPT with how it contrasts so sharply to basically every other champion in the League. Every other champion is a legendary beast, a mighty warrior, an ancient myth, a nightmare story told to whimpering children. All of these champions are powerful, might beings, with unknown might, and unknown goals. But what does Yorick do? He digs graves. He doesn't go around destroying entire towns, he doesn't lead mighty armies, he doesn't create fantastical magic items, or technologies, he just digs graves. Why does he dig graves? Because graves need to be dug. People are always dying, and they need to go somewhere. 

Yorick is interesting BECAUSE of his contrast to other characters, especially Shadow Isle characters. The creatures of the Shadow Isles always seem wicked, and sinister, but Yorick is just there, doing his job. He seems like one of the only Shadow Isles champions that you could run into and he wouldn't kill you/torture you/enslave you/feast on your soul/lifeblood. Yorick simply has better things to do. Yorick simply can't be bothered with conflict, or plots, and plans, he has graves to dig, he's too busy for this. He's a perfect example of the "I'm too old for this sh*t." Character, which is a really cool character concept, because that sort of character is the one who has, in this case maybe literally, seen it ALL. He's been everywhere, seen everything, and it's impossible to surprise him anymore. Yorick seems kinda like this sort of Runeterra-wide legend, he goes where graves need to be dug, and he digs graves. He's a bad omen, he's bad luck, where he goes, War, Famine, Pestilence, and Death follow him(Thus the names of his ghouls!). Similar to how Bard goes around watching over ancient artifacts, and mighty relics to keep the world from falling into chaos, so too does Yorick go around ensuring the souls of the dead don't roam free willy nilly. He puts bodies in the ground, and makes sure their souls move on.

Which leads into some FANTASTIC story opportunities for him. His ghouls may not just be dead people, they may actually be representations of War, Pestilence, and Famine. Yorick's powers stem from the power of death, all the things that cause it. His job is to send dead souls to where they need to go, so what happens when they get redirected? Or start wandering where they shouldn't? Yorick is the guy who would go handle that. Beings like Thresh, Kalista, Mordekaiser etc. these people take, twist, and command the souls of others. So would Yorick go after them? Would he free the souls from their command, and send them to their inevitable destination? Or does he see them as just a different sort of destination for souls? Does it not matter where they go, as long as they don't roam free on their own?

Yorick has tons of opportunity, because he has such a simple, but focused job. Yorick digs graves. He's the creepy old grave digger whose been everywhere and back, and simply doesn't care about most things anymore, because he's got a job to do, and he'll be dammed(again) if it doesn't get done.

Yorick Mori has pride. Pride in his lineage, pride in his duty, and pride in himself. There is no finer gravedigger to be found in all the lands. His job is to put the body in the ground, and the soul into the beyond. He is a master of his craft, and he fills a position very unappreciated but very vital. Yorick takes pride that he does the job his family has done for generations, and does it right.
He may not have much, but his pride in his duty is all that he needs. And if you get in the way of his duty, he'll put you in the ground as well.
